in_class_description_detail: Extensive, rather dry, rocky highland plains on flat or sloping land. The surface is mostly sand and pumice, but in some places frost hemlocks are widespread. There is a lot of driftwood and sand drift. The overall vegetation cover is very low. Mosses in crevices and in the shelter of rocks, but scabrous lichens and sedges on rocks.

Wet to dry riverbeds with glacial and glacial channels and meltwater channels. The surface is slightly sloping and rather smooth but unstable due to the presence and encroachment of water. Vegetation cover is very low and the vegetation is very low-growing. Vegetation is denser where the water recedes and encroachment is less, especially the moss Racomitrium ericoides which forms the greatest cover there.

Areas where the surface is covered with ice all year round or nearly so; glaciers, ice caps, glaciers, crevasses and glacier remnants (glaciers) (H4.2). Also crevasses and rock outcrops and ledges on top of glacial ice (H4.3).
efg_name: Ice sheets, glaciers and perennial snowfields
efg_description: T6.1 Ice sheets, glaciers and perennial snowfields

in_class_description_detail: Very well-vegetated land, flat to sloping, dry to clayey, in some places somewhat rocky with a high organic soil content supported by helmoss ( Anthelia juratzkana ). Vegetation cover is variable, alternating with fully vegetated areas and bare ground. Vegetation is very low-growing and shaped by snowdrifts. The cover of vascular plants and especially lichens is small, but the cover of the moss melagambra ( Racomitrium ericoides ) is considerable in some places. The habitat is found mainly in depressions in mountainous areas and on river banks in snowy areas.

Well-developed to fully vegetated mossy ground on slopes, slopes and on undulating land in rainy or humid areas to the mountains. Vegetation is characterized by the moss melagambra ( Racomitrium ericoides ), which forms a thin to continuous but loose vegetation layer. The organic soil cover is also extensive. The surface is quite rocky but the substrate is uneven; gravel, sand, pumice and tuff. Vegetation is generally very low-growing and sparsely vegetated.

A low-sloping, dry sandy area inland with 1–3 m high sedge mounds. Between the mounds are gravel or sand. The surface is very unstable because sand blows from one place and accumulates in another under the shelter of plants. Vegetation is rather sparse and shaped by sand drift. Vascular plants, especially sedge and meadowsweet, are completely dominant. Mosses and lichens are hardly found.

The habitat is characterized by a high cover of lava sphagnum. It is found on hilly ridges, both on heaths and in lowlands, especially where there is little snow. It is generally quite well overgrown and the overall moss cover is high. The cover of vascular plants is considerable and the lichen cover is significant, especially the cover of reindeer sedges, which in many places give the habitat its character. The land is quite rocky in some places and the rocks protrude from the moss. Vegetation is generally very short.

Extensive heathland bogs with a distinctive pattern of long tussock beds (rima) and pre-wetted floodplains between them that lie across or in a slight bend from the land slope. Ponds and small ponds in the depressions. Water mostly originates from higher ground around, flows down from the slope, is rather mineral-rich and the bogs are therefore quite fertile. Peat and sedge vegetation grows on the ridges, while floodplain vegetation grows in the depressions. The land is very well vegetated and the vegetation is tall. Vascular plant cover is rather sparse, moss is abundant in the sedges and dominant, especially on the ridges, there are very few lichens.

Slightly to very well-vegetated, gently sloping apal and helluhava, mostly free of soft sand and pumice on the surface. Vegetation is very low (<5 cm) and is characterized by sphagnum lichens ( Stereocaulon sp.) and organic soil cover (mostly helmoss) which gives the lavas a special appearance. The ecosystem is found both in areas with high rainfall in the south of the country where the mosses melagambi ( Racomitrium ericoides ) and lava sphagnum ( R. lanuginosum ) are prominent in the cover and in drier areas in the north where sphagnum lichens and organic soil cover dominate. Vascular plant cover is sparse.
efg_name: Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes
efg_description: T3.4 Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes

in_class_description_detail: Slightly vegetated, porous lava, from modern times. The lavas are generally low-sloping slab lavas or apal lavas, in some places sand and pumice-rich. Stability is variable and is determined by sand and pumice on the surface. Vegetation cover is variable but generally very low. Vegetation is low-growing primitive vegetation with vascular plants, mosses and lichens having a similar cover.
efg_name: Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes
efg_description: T3.4 Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes

in_class_description: L14.1 Þéttbýli og annað manngert land
in_class_description_detail: Buildings and related structures; cities, towns, villages, industrial areas, power plants, roads, ports and airports, waste disposal areas, mines, etc.

Low-growing (tallest trees >1m), discontinuous forests and thickets of birch and heather, on rather dry to clayey land, on lava fields, moors, bogs, hollows and on landslide-eroded slopes. The surface is uneven and in many places quite uneven. The undergrowth is very dense, the birch crown is sparse, the cover of vascular plants is quite extensive, mosses are prominent in the black layer and there is a small amount of lichen. The soil is rather shallow and rocks or pebbles are common.

Silvicultural areas with old or young cultivated forests, where foreign conifers and/or deciduous trees (eg Siberian larch, Scots pine, Sitka spruce, Alaskan aspen) or native tree species (birch) have been planted in sparsely forested or forestless areas.

Very well-vegetated modern lava, usually low-sloping apel or slab lava. Extensive cover of vascular plants, especially heather species, and mosses (lavender moss) and lichens. Surface stability is uneven, vegetation cover is variable and erosion scars are prominent in some places. Vegetation is low.

Very lush flowerbed of Alaskan lupine, grasses and flowering plants. Found increasingly on protected land where lupine has been sown or planted and it spreads through mud, loam, landslides, hollows and heather peat. The land is well overgrown, vegetation is tall, vascular plants are dominant, considerable moss layer in the soil where rainfall is high.

Areas where grasses have been sown for revegetation and fertilizer spread, on sand, gravel, roadsides, and other disturbed areas. Grasses generally persist with repeated fertilization but wither and disappear after it is stopped within a few years. Where conditions are favorable, vegetation develops into moss and peatland over the years.

in_class_description: L14.6 Skógarkerfill og fleiri áþekkar tegundir
in_class_description_detail: A very lush flowerbed, mainly formed by forest nettle, to a lesser extent, common nettle or other invasive, nitrogen-loving species. Found increasingly on protected land near urban areas, in roadsides, old fields and lupine fields where the soil is fertile and rather moist. The land is very well vegetated, the vegetation is very tall, dense and sparsely varied.

Mossy, porous lava from modern times, slightly sloping, slab-on-grade lava. The surface is generally stable and there is little loose sand or pumice. The total vegetation cover is on average high but varies between well-vegetated depressions and less vegetated lava mounds and ridges. Moss is completely dominant in the vegetation cover, mostly lava beds that characterize the habitat. Vascular plants are sparse and lichens are few. Vegetation is very low-growing.
efg_name: Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes
efg_description: T3.4 Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes

in_class_description_detail: The beach bed is characterized by hard rocks and boulders. This, together with the surf, determines a lot about the living conditions and how the ecosystem is divided into sub-categories. Other physical factors that shape the ecosystem are the slope of the beach, the difference between high and low tide, sea temperature and salinity. In pebble and boulder beaches, algae have better stability and are more resistant to surf than in beaches where the substrate is looser. Larger algae only grow where the substrate is firm enough and does not topple over in a surf. The more the surf, the more stable the substrate must be for algae to thrive. They also do not thrive well in pebble and boulder beaches where loose gravel and sand are washed up by the waves and scrape vegetation from the substrate. However, small annual algae can grow temporarily in such places while the sea is calm in the summer. In very rough and rocky beaches, where little algae grows, scabbardfish are often conspicuous.
efg_name: Cross-referenced to 255 due to incompatible class descriptions
efg_description: No Data (data exists in source maps but cross-referenced to no data due to incompatible class descriptions)

in_class_description_detail: Marine lagoons are separated from the sea by some form of obstruction that significantly restricts tidal flow, such as sandbars, lava fields and roads (Agnar Ingólfsson 2005). Estuaries at marine lagoons are either open or closed and access to the sea varies. Tides are delayed in entering the lagoons, they are reduced or even non-existent, and the outflow usually takes longer than the inflow. In some lagoons, the sea rises at every high tide, in others only very rarely. Due to reduced tides, the shores of marine lagoons are often rather small. Estuaries can widen or narrow, due to natural causes or due to human activities, and the lagoons can change greatly as a result (Agnar Ingólfsson 1990, 2005).The salinity of marine lagoons varies and depends on factors such as freshwater inflow, storm frequency, tides and sea inflow into the lagoon. Salinity usually ranges from 10 salinities up to full-salt water (35 S). Biodiversity is often quite sparse and generally decreases with lower salinity, in addition to the type of coastal bed affecting species composition. In rare cases, marine species, such as the coastal eel Gammarus dubeni , are found in brackish lakes near the sea (Agnar Ingólfsson 1990) and such waters are not considered marine lagoons. The boundaries between marine lagoons, estuaries and coastal waters are often unclear, but salinity is usually used to distinguish between them. If salinity was unknown, aerial photographs were used to assess how easy sea access is to the lagoon.The description of marine lagoons is based almost exclusively on the work of Agnar Ingólfsson (1990), which covers lagoons larger than 10 ha. On the coast, however, there are more and smaller lagoons that could probably be classified as marine lagoons, but they are all almost unexplored. Marine lagoons are classified into high-saline lagoons and clay lagoons, among other things according to salinity, type of estuary, tides and shoreline. For example, high-saline lagoons usually have high salinity, while it varies in clay lagoons.
efg_name: Intermittently closed and open lakes and lagoons
efg_description: FM1.3 Intermittently closed and open lakes and lagoons

in_class_description_detail: Lightly to very well-vegetated erosion areas and erosion margins, erosion belts and soils, which are either inflating or regrowing after erosion. The ecosystem usually forms a rather narrow belt between old-vegetated dry land and slightly moist land such as silt and rocks. Closer to the erosion belts, the surface is dry, unstable and very sparsely vegetated. The surface is generally smooth but the slope is uneven. Vegetation cover is very variable. The vegetation, which consists largely of vascular plants, is under great stress due to erosion and erosion. Moss and lichen cover is insignificant.

Very lush grassland and flowerbeds on bird cliffs and islands, heavily influenced by sea salinity and fertilization from seabirds. Vegetation varies depending on the growing site; common sedge, common sedge, etc. species are common on cliffs, but purer grasslands with meadowsweet, field creeping grass and flowering plants on the plains above the shore and the banks. Slopes range from plains to steep slopes. Vegetation is mostly tall, vascular plants dominate but there are few mosses and lichens.

Small, loose, sandy, rather dry scree on flat and sloping land. Sand drifts are common in many places. Vegetation is very low, grassy and sparse. Total vegetation cover is very low but variable, mostly vascular plants.

Stable, well-vegetated, dry sand dunes, in some places with shallow depressions, above the seashore where sand has accumulated and the land has grown up. The ecosystem has in most cases developed from coastal sedge habitat. Mosses and vascular plants form the main vegetation cover and lichens are found to some extent. Vegetation is medium-high.

Flat floodplains by the sea overgrown with yellow sedge and other wetland species, at estuaries and major stream margins and above, at the bottom of bays and fjords where the effects of tides and salt water are felt. Very lush land, vascular plants are dominant, mosses are found to some extent but lichens are very few.

Small to very well vegetated sand dunes on sea ridges and sands, overgrown with fennel ( Leymus arenarius ) and fescue ( Festuca rubra ssp. richardsonii ). Almost plant-free sand between dunes. Constant movement of sand that accumulates on the sides of the dunes that build up and erode alternately. Land under great stress from wind, sand drifts and sea currents. Vascular plants completely dominant, mosses and lichens are scarcely found.

Well-vegetated, wetland area on the seashore, at the upper limit of the tide but at or below the high tide limit. The fens are gently sloping, often with fens, puddles and small ponds. The sea flows over the fens during high tide and floods. The ecosystem is therefore strongly influenced by the sea. Vegetation is widely zoned, with sea fen and cat's tongue dominating at the bottom, while meadowsweet and creeping grass take over higher up. Vegetation is rather low-growing and often heavily grazed by geese, swans and sheep. It is characterized by vascular plants, but mosses and lichens are found in very small numbers.

Gravel and rock ridges by the sea are sparsely vegetated. The habitat is found mainly in bays and coves where the sea has thrown up sand, gravel and rocks. Due to the sea current, the surface is very unstable and the vegetation is heavily influenced by the sea. The surface is very rocky, the vegetation is sparse or in small patches, low-growing and very diverse. It consists mainly of vascular plants, but mosses and lichens are only found in very small quantities.

Basalt and shell sand beaches with sparse coastal vegetation consisting mostly of salt-tolerant vascular plant species. Mosses and lichens are rare or absent. Seaweed is often abundant, which has a fertilizing effect on the vegetation. In places where the sea current is weak, the vegetation is generally zonal.
efg_name: Cross-referenced to 255 due to incompatible class descriptions
efg_description: No Data (data exists in source maps but cross-referenced to no data due to incompatible class descriptions)

in_class_description_detail: Well-vegetated wetland patches where water emerges on rocky or gravelly slopes to the mountains and at the foot of slopes, characterized by continuous moss beds with a scattering of vascular plants, vegetation is low-growing. Often forms prominent, yellow-green vegetation patches to the mountains. The surface is sloping and slightly uneven, the soil is water-permeable and the groundwater flow is fairly even throughout the year. The moss beds are very dense, the vascular plant cover is low and lichens are rarely found.

Flat, well-vegetated, lush and fertile yellowstone ravines and floodplains, especially along rivers and lakes. Groundwater is mineral-rich, mobile and high all year round, but land is usually submerged during winter and spring floods. The ecosystem is therefore productive and the vegetation is very tall. Vascular plants are dominant, but there is some moss cover, lichens are rare.

Flat, flat and open, often very extensive, fertile land with diverse vegetation, where horsetail makes an impression on the vegetation due to its height but is not a dominant species. The land is well vegetated and the vegetation is moderately tall, mosses are prominent in the soil but there are very few lichens.

Flat to slightly sloping, wet to slightly wet bogland, overgrown with sedge and sturgeon, in ravines and on plains where water stands high and is slow moving, rather poor in minerals, small ponds and meadows common. On tussocks and ridges, clover and other dryland species grow. The land is very well overgrown and the vegetation is quite tall, vascular plants are dominant and some moss is present, there is a small amount of lichen on tussocks and ridges.
efg_name: Boreal, temperate and montane peat bogs
efg_description: TF1.6 Boreal, temperate and montane peat bogs

in_class_description_detail: Semi-vegetated, rocky, sloping moors on hillsides, on eroded ridges and ridges; found from lowlands to mountains where precipitation is abundant but snow cover is low. The ecosystem is characterized by a fairly extensive cover of the mosses lava moors and melagambræ and is also the most vegetated moor ecosystem in the country. However, the cover is patchy, alternating with moss beds, moor patches and sedges. There is some vascular plant cover and lichens are quite prominent. Vegetation is generally very low-growing.

Fully vegetated, flat or slightly sloping, very mossy wetland with bays, ponds, marshy patches and moors to heaths and mountains. Bay vegetation is found near ponds and in depressions, but peatland vegetation is found on moors. Vegetation is rather low and sparse except where pondweed grows. Mosses dominate the cover and their diversity is high. Lichens are few.

Flat and level, fertile marshland, wet to semi-wet, overgrown with marsh sedge and other wetland species, in valley bottoms and on floodplains of streams near the sea. Water stands high, is moving and rich in minerals. The land is overgrown and the vegetation is rather tall, vascular plants are dominant but moss cover is extensive, lichens are not found due to the wetness.

Slightly to moderately sloping, wet to wet, swampy land covered with marsh sedge and other wetland species, on plains and slopes. On tussocks and ridges, clover and other dryland species grow. Groundwater is high but the land is little or not flooded during floods and thaws, the water is rather mineral-rich and the land fertile. It is evergreen, the vegetation is very tall, vascular plants are dominant but moss is abundant, lichens are rarely found. This category includes fens, but in them fens can have as much cover as or more than fens.

Very well-vegetated, moist and gently sloping, mossy land on heaths and mountains, often with small streams and wetlands, marsh vegetation is in the depressions but peatland plants on drier ridges and tussocks. There may be some erosion on the surface and clay and sand after dissolution. Vegetation is low-growing and rather sparse, vascular plant cover is sparse, but mosses are very dense, there are very few lichens. Organic soil content is quite high.
efg_name: Boreal, temperate and montane peat bogs
efg_description: TF1.6 Boreal, temperate and montane peat bogs

in_class_description_detail: Slightly to moderately sloping, clayey to wet, swampy land on plains, humps and slopes, overgrown with small shrubs, sedges and other wetland species, abundant sphagnum moss ( Sphagnum ) in tussocks and on ridges. Water levels are high but land is little or not flooded during floods and thaws. Land is grassy, ??moderately fertile and vegetation is quite tall. Vascular plants are dominant but moss is very abundant in the sedges, lichens are rarely found.

Algae-rich, flat or slightly sloping, moist to wet, mossy and sedge-covered bogs with shrub vegetation on the heath and in the lower part of the highlands. Vascular plant and moss cover is extensive but lichen cover is low. Vegetation is all-round tall and lush. Surface rather uniform, alternating with wet depressions with marsh sedge and winter sedge and drier areas overgrown with blueberry heather, mountain ash and other shrubs. There are few ponds and pools.

A gently sloping, well-vegetated, mossy wetland with diverse vegetation, high up in the mountains, where the average annual temperature is around or below -2 Cº. The surface is variable, with ponds, bays, small streams and ruins with ice lenses, usually covered with lichen-rich peatland vegetation. The vegetation density and height vary, mostly in the wetlands between ruins.
efg_name: Boreal, temperate and montane peat bogs
efg_description: TF1.6 Boreal, temperate and montane peat bogs

in_class_description_detail: Flat, well-vegetated, open, sparse wetlands and marshes along rivers and in depressions where water overflows in gullies and sand, pumice and finer sediments are deposited and deposited in the soil. The surface is generally smooth and ponds are characteristic of the habitat in some places. Vegetation is moderately tall, vascular plants are rather sparse, but in many places quite rich in moss.
efg_name: Boreal, temperate and montane peat bogs
efg_description: TF1.6 Boreal, temperate and montane peat bogs

in_class_description_detail: Slightly sloping, wet to very wet bays on flatlands and in ravines, overgrown with pond sedge, winter sedge and other wetland species. Water levels are high and land is submerged during floods and low tides, there is generally little movement of water but the land is very fertile. The ecosystem is well vegetated and the vegetation is tall, vascular plants are dominant but moss is abundant in the swamps, lichens are rarely found due to the wetness.

Flowery, lush grassland or herbaceous plant stand on sheltered and sunny slopes and slopes, facing south and southwest. Land on a slight to moderate slope. It is well vegetated and the vegetation is quite tall. Vascular plant cover is extensive and the moss layer is also dense, but there are very few lichens.

Well-vegetated, somewhat rocky, rather dry screes on heaths and in the mountains, especially on land that has begun to grow somewhat. The surface is generally stable and there is little sand drift. Vegetation is very low. The coverage of vascular plants, mosses and organic soil cover is similar, but lichen cover is rather low.

Rather sparse grassland, overgrown with sedge and other grass species but also with broadleaf plants. Found mainly on the lower slopes and slopes and therefore usually at some slope. In many places, large boulders protrude from the vegetation. The ecosystem is well vegetated and the vegetation is moderately tall. Vascular plants dominate the cover, but mosses are quite abundant in the sward. Lichens are found to some extent.

Thick, rather lush grassland, overgrown with meadowsweet, meadowsweet, bluegrass and marsh sedge and in some places very tall clumps of hairy willow and yellow willow. Found on sloping land in valley bottoms in lowlands and on heaths and also on drained land. The land is slightly sloping, very well vegetated and the vegetation is rather tall. Vascular plants dominate the cover, moss cover is quite extensive but there are few lichens.

Rather uniform, sparse grassland overgrown with sedge and various grass and peatland species. Sedge is completely dominant in most places and forms prominent light patches in the landscape. The habitat is found on slopes and knolls in lowlands and on heaths, but only in snowy areas where snow remains long after spring. The land is generally on a considerable slope and very well vegetated. Vegetation is moderately tall, vascular plants dominate the vegetation cover and some moss in the sward. Lichen cover is very low.

Lush grassland covered with alpine meadow grass, meadow fescue and other grassland species. The habitat is found on moist to dry land on slopes and slopes, but also on flat land, including drained land. The soil is thick and fertile. The land is very well vegetated, vegetation is moderately tall, vascular plants are dominant and some moss is present. There are very few lichens.

Very lush grassland on flatlands and slopes, overgrown with rush and other grassland species. The habitat is found mainly in lowlands in old cropland and pasture where the soil is rather thick and fertile. The land is grassy, ??the vegetation is tall, vascular plants completely dominate, moss is scarce, lichens are rarely found.

Rather sparse, sparse and dry, mossy grassland overgrown with sedge and other grass and peatland species. The land is gently sloping, grassy, ??vegetation rather low-growing for grassland, vascular plants dominant. Moss is abundant and conspicuous in appearance, there are a few lichens.

Dry, generally dense, well-vegetated peatland covered with mountain sedge, heather, blueberry heather and other peatland species, rich in mosses and lichens. Rather gently sloping land in lowlands and heathland. Vegetation is rather low-growing, vascular plants predominate, but moss cover is quite extensive and lichen cover is significant in most places.

Dry, dense, lichen- and moss-rich peatland overgrown with heather, willow, blueberry heather and other peatland species. Light lichens ( Cladonia ) are prominent in the vegetation. Rather gently sloping land in weathered areas on outcrops and heaths, rocks are usually visible on the surface. The land is well vegetated, vegetation is low-growing, vascular plant cover is rather sparse, but mosses dominate the cover, lichen cover is extensive and greater than in other habitats.

Grassy, ??smooth to dense peatland overgrown with heather, bloodstone, grasses and other peatland species, often on a considerable slope. In many places, rocks are visible on the surface. The land is well overgrown, vegetation is rather low-growing, vascular plants dominate, moss is quite abundant and there are a few lichens.

Well-vegetated, dry to mushy, moss-rich but not very lush heather and willow peatlands in the highlands. The habitat is found on flat to sloping land on steep slopes, which increases diversity. Vegetation is low-growing, the cover of vascular plants and mosses is similar but lichens are rather sparse. The surface is widely eroded and frost hemlocks are present on the surface.

Permeable silty and pumice-mixed sands and gravels at the foot of slopes, hills and mountain slopes and in some places on flat land. The surface is very unstable and characterized by uneven silty and pumice sands that are added by weathering. The land is in some places completely rocky in places. The land is sparsely vegetated and mosses dominate. Vegetation is very low.
efg_name: Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes
efg_description: T3.4 Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes

in_class_description_detail: Dry and dense peatland overgrown with heather, blueberry heather, pasture heather and other low-growing heather and peatland species, often on steep slopes, on slopes, ridges and humps. The land is well overgrown, the vegetation is low-growing, vascular plants dominate, moss is abundant and there are a few lichens.

Dry, well-vegetated, moss-rich peatland, with a sparse cover of vascular plants, especially herbaceous species, sedges, heather and bloodstone. Moss peat habitat is most common on slopes and foothills, but is also found on flat land along streams, rivers and on vegetated river banks.

Rather dry, highly eroded, dense peatland, usually arid and on a slight slope, with flakes and stones on the surface, overgrown with holtasole, krikkeulen, tursa-beard and other peatland species, rich in lichens, generally shaped by heavy grazing. Vegetation fast-growing, vascular plants are dominant, quite a few mosses and mostly lichens.

Dry to clayey, rather gently sloping, grassy and mossy peatland on heaths and mountains, overgrown with sedge, willow grass and other peatland species. The habitat is found mainly on the border of wetlands and drier peatlands, along rivers and streambeds and between wetlands and mela. It is well vegetated, vegetation is low, mosses are dominant, there is considerable vascular plant cover and some lichen cover.

Dry to moist, lush scrubland in the lowlands, at the foothills and slopes and in lush areas in the mountains, covered with yellow willow, hairy willow, heather and other peatland species. The land is well vegetated, the vegetation is rather tall, vascular plants are dominant, mosses are abundant but lichens are rather scarce. Angelica and other tall flowering plants such as bluegrass and burdock are prominent in some places.

Dry to moist, well-vegetated peatlands with hairy willow, mountain willow, heather and other peatland species. The habitat is found in the lowlands and in the central highlands, especially on flat or slightly sloping alluvial plains. Soil is widely sandy and in snowy areas the cover of organic soil is significant. Vegetation is rather low-growing. The cover of sedges and mosses is quite extensive, but the cover of lichens is small.

Steep, very unstable but irregular basalt, tuff and liparite landslides. Total vegetation cover is very low and generally less than in other landslide habitats and in habitats in general. Vegetation is very low, vascular plants are dominant but there is little moss and lichen due to the high movement of the substrate. Vegetation patches and some greenery are mostly found on boulders and solid rocks where there is a break from rock slides.
efg_name: Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes
efg_description: T3.4 Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes

in_class_description_detail: Lush bog and marshland near hot springs, marshes, pools and geysers. Drier patches are also found in between. The land is flat or slightly sloping. Species composition can vary quite a bit. Vascular plants are most prominent in the cover, while mosses are most prominent where soil temperatures are highest.

Hot and dry ground, especially on hills and ridges near steam and clay hot springs. Where steam rises, it carries moisture with it, which can create conditions for moisture-loving species. The soil is strongly affected by temperature, and where it is most abundant, mosses dominate the cover. Vegetation cover is usually fragmented and light clay flakes are prominent. At lower temperatures, vegetation cover is more continuous and the proportion of vascular plants is greater.
efg_name: Cross-referenced to 255 due to incompatible class descriptions
efg_description: No Data (data exists in source maps but cross-referenced to no data due to incompatible class descriptions)

in_class_description_detail: Patches of clay and mud in the foothills, hollows and depressions of the highlands or where hot water flows from springs and hot springs. As you move higher up the slopes, the land becomes drier and steam and clay geysers are found there. Snow-dampening effects on vegetation can be seen in many places. Vegetation cover is generally uninterrupted where it is wetter. Mosses are prominent in the cover, but vascular plants often grow sparsely.

A fairly diverse habitat at hot springs, steam vents or hot springs. It is characterized by a sparsely vegetated surface that is variously clay, hot spring crust, pumice or lava but can also have the appearance of chalk. Deposits are widespread and sulfur tufts occur. The surface of the habitat is often colorful, with light and red colors prominent. The surface ranges from being very porous to very hard and dense. Vegetation is patchy and species composition is determined by temperature and moisture in the soil.

Steep, generally stable, very large and rough basalt and liparite landslides and screes. There is some vegetation, mosses at the base, also a little lichen but very little vascular plants. Vegetation is therefore very low-growing. Mossy lava beds characterize most landslides in this category and form wide continuous beds on top of the boulders.
efg_name: Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes
efg_description: T3.4 Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes

in_class_description_detail: Steep, unstable to fairly stable, basalt and tuff landslides. Surface roughness varies greatly, from small boulders to large boulders. Vegetation is very low and the land is sparsely vegetated, with sphagnum mosses dominating.
efg_name: Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes
efg_description: T3.4 Young rocky pavements, lava flows and screes

in_class_description_detail: Rather dry, gently sloping riverbanks and alluvial plains with glacial channels and tributaries. Surface slightly undulating and shaped by water flow, alternating with well-vegetated channels and bare ridges. Surface rather stable, in some places quite rocky. Land with very low-growing primary vegetation, sphagnum mosses dominant but scattered with vascular plants and lichens.

in_class_description_detail: Fields and fields; agricultural land where perennial (meadow grasses) and annual (cereals, potatoes, vegetables) crops are grown.

in_class_description_detail: Rather small lakes on vegetated flatlands. The watershed is generally well vegetated. The banks of the lake are well vegetated and rocky shorelines are rarely present. The lakes are very shallow (<2 m) and the water basin is fairly uniform in depth. Aerial vegetation (plants that grow out of the water) is prominent along the banks.

in_class_description_detail: Spring rivers and spring-fed rivers on the younger bedrock of the country (<0.8 million years old). The sources are in springs and the rivers are characterized by a constant flow and water temperature that is also low year-round, especially closest to the sources. Erosion of water banks is low and the banks are often well vegetated. The rivers do not bury themselves much because the river discharge is low. Eddy currents are dominant, but sections of river with laminar flow can occur.
